The days grow colder, the nights grow longer. That means /co/ Christmas cheer is coming to town. Grab some cocoa, turn on the Christmas music, get comfy, and hang out with some /co/mrades as we share stories and get into the holiday spirit.

As in previous years, share your Amazon wishlist and some random Anon may purchase a holiday gift for you. Be sure to gift another Anon in return so we can spread the cheer far and wide. Unfortunately, some Anons, such as those in Chile, cannot be gifted via Amazon because of an issue regarding ID information need for shipping.

To get your wishlist code, open your wishlist on Amazon. The link will look like this: amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/###########. Share the ########### with the thread to be added to the pastebins, and be sure to denote which site you're using (such as .ca, .co.uk, etc). Before posting your list, make sure to hit the "..." in the upper right corner and go into "Manage list". From there, set the privacy of the list to Public, select a shipping address for the list, and check off the options to "Share my shipping address with sellers" and "Let buyers ship additional items not on this list to my shipping address."

Last year we had 132 gifted anons, some more than once.

Ungifted lists: pastebin.com/SmVHgMRE
All lists: pastebin.com/ZCXuvfE5

posts.name: Calendar Man
posts.com:
Let's start Friday, December 17th, 1954 with a bit of spy intrigue, as Irmgard Margarete Schmidt was arrested in West Berlin - a spy for the Soviets, she tried to honeypot one of the officials there, but was caught by US intelligence agents after being fed false information. But who knows how much correct information she sent over the Iron Curtain in the 18 months before she got caught.
While nabbing a spy working for the glorious country of the Proletariat could only very arguably be considered a move against the workers, the next on most certainly is. You see, British European Airlines had just sacked 315 of their employees at London Airport - about a quarter of the workforce there - for taking an unauthorized break. They did it to discuss how they should respond to their union representative only getting paid a fraction of his rate when focusing on union matters.
I had another factoid I thought was for this day, but when I went back to double-check as I was writing this post, it turned out it happened a year earlier. And this is why you should double-check everything you learn from wikipedia and why you should NOT give them a dime.

posts.name: SHEOL
posts.com:
WELCOME ONE AND ALL TO THE FESTIVE MOVIE TIME OF PAIN!

Every year we gather to watch some of the wort trash spat out in the name of the holiday season. Come join us, get something to eat, and sit there bemused with the rest of us. We have, in order:

CHRISTMAS IN NEW YORK
What happens when a jungle boy rides a giant living tree across the ocean to New York in the hope of finding his parents? He reunites with a talking dog, of course! ... Yeah, this actually happens... it's nuts from wall to wall.

RAPSITTIE STREET KIDS: BELIEVE IN SANTA
Formally lost media, this money laundering scheme recruited the voice talents of Mark Hamill. However, it's the visual equivalent of Salvadore Dali headbutting bucks of paint after suffering a stroke.

WE WISH YOU A TURTLES CHRISTMAS
Join your favourite shell-heads played by actors in horrific animatronic costumes as they sing and dance through their own versions of Christmas songs, including reggae. Will they ever get a gift for Splinter?

THE STAR WARS HOLIDAY SPECIAL
The infamous nightmare itself, endure Wookies cracking one off to VR porn in the living room, bizarre skits, Carrie Fisher off her tits on coke and a Millenium Falcon set made of cardboard.

And finally, HOME SWEET HOME ALONE
The remake-slash-sequel of the classic is utter garbage, even down to its very premise.

WATCH HERE AT 1PM GMT (about 2 and a half hours from this) AT: https://vaughn.live/sheol_uk

posts.name: Calendar Man
posts.com:
Tuesday, December 18th, 1951 finds us smack-dab in the middle od the Korean War, where during talks the Communist side released a list of 11.559 Allied prisoners, including 3198 Americans (among them Major General William F. Dean, apparently beloved by his company and considered by everyone but them to b KIA) and 919 Brits – still much less than the over on hundred thousand considered MIA since the start of the war. The Allies replied with a list of over 130 thousand POWs they've captured.
International Court in Hague decreed that Norway's idea for what it considers territorial waters with exclusive fishing rights is not contrary to International Law. Which might not seem like a big case, but with the hullabaloo the Brits were making over Norway's new-fangled idea of "baseline" rather than measuring from the coast at low tide, and the fact that currently that very idea is recognized as standard, I wouldn't be surprised if this was what led to current laws being implemented in the first place.
And in Saucy gossip news, movie producer Walter Wanger was indicted by a grand jury on one count of assault with intent to murder – he suspected his wife, the actress Joan Bennett, has had an affair with her long-time agent, Jennings Lang, whom he shot. He spent four months in Pitchess and returned to making movies, among which was, inspired by what he had gone through, "Riot in Cell Block 11", "the best prison film ever made" according to Tarantino.

Honestly don’t know what I would do with superpowers.
Not bitter enough to become a villain or go full despot and do whatever I want.
Not naive enough to think I could eliminate all suffering in the world and make everyone happy.
If you start doing good deeds, even if you limit it to a certain area, people are eventually going to rely on you for everything and you’re locked in, so if you suddenly decide to quit one day everyone will think you abandoned them.
Unironically I think I’d actually want some kind of nemesis or rival to keep my motivated.
Otherwise I really just think I’d just use my powers to fly around the world for free and then do normal traveler shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Tighten is the most realistic portrayal of "nobody loser suddenly gets superpowers" ever put to film. Sure, you can say you would be a good guy and wouldn't fall to temptation, but absolute power corrupts absolutely and even the most seemingly benevolent people would start selfishly abusing their powers or would start twisting things and become more extreme in their use.

>>134595875
It would be almost impossible to be a genuine good guy anyway. Unless you just stuck to stopping small time things like robberies, you’d eventually run into a situation where you’d have to solve it based on your own standard of justice or right/wrong which would inevitably ruffle someone’s feathers. And then that would open the floodgate to people trying to trash your reputation because you didn’t come up with a perfect answer.
If you were going for world peace or something, it wouldn’t really work if your solution is just “play nice or I’ll beat you up” since that means it wouldn’t be true peace and people are just living in fear of you.

I don’t even mean the main characters, I mean how every background character is an interchangeable NPC, and there’s only like 5 designs for them total. I 100% believe this is because SEGA were even more super anal about what is and isn’t ok for Sonic character designs and so the creators just said “fuck it that’s enough we’ll just recolour and copy-paste the rest” after they spent months and months desperately tryna get Iizuka to approve of the character models they sent him for evaluation one after another.

>nobody on this board seems to know about it
Now that’s a fucking lie. We’ve been spammed with John K fags since the dawn of this website.

What I’d like to know, that nobody has ever been able to articulate to me, is WHY Tereytoons above all else? It’s not like they were the only boomer cartoons on, and most people not trying to be contrarians see them as more soulless than other studios. If you have to pick a “forgotten “ cartoon studio to champion, why Terry in particular? Why them over Columbia’s Cartoon Rhapsody, Universal’s Lantz works, Pal’s Puppetoons, etc. - they’re just as obscure. The only period where Terrytoons was super interesting and making great stuff was in the late 50s when Gene Deitch was producing some things and they had a cool -not quite UPA- no such thing as a bad idea style going for them. Shorts like Flebus and The Juggler of Our Lady were hidden gems in a time when cartoons were dying. And yet the Terryfags don’t even want to talk about this era. I’ve already spoiled my theory that the fandom is based around being able to loosely connect it to John K, but if you think I’m wrong please enlighten me as to why you think this studio is special.

I understand there's a strong nostalgic attachment. But me saying
>It's not like they were the only boomer cartoons on
is because I see a disproportionate amount of old cartoonfags simping for Terrytoons above other things that were airing. Even if Disney kept a lot of their stuff theatrical only, tv programming still had Fleischer/Famous, Universal, MGM, WB, Screen Gems, Van Bueren, etc. not to mention made-for-tv offerings like Jay Ward and Hanna Barbera. Nostalgia alone doesn't explain why there are always Terrytoons stans proclaiming the cartoons are the greatest on every old cartoon forum when other stuff was airing at the same time. I don't want to be too autistic about it, people like what they like, but the way these cartoons are talked about has always seemed suspicious/influenced by cults of personality.

Knock it off with this crap, Avengers was historically one of Marvel's better selling books through the 60s, 70s and 80s, and again through the mid-90s onwards. Even most of the lesser runs still sold like a B-tier book.

I swear everyone on /co/ looks at the early 90s and nothing else when talking about how books "historically" sold, for the sake of the narrative that only X-Men and Spider-Man ever sold.

Avengers started off as a team of characters who all had their own solo books, it later added characters like Hawkeye, Quicksilver, Scarlet Witch, Vision and Black Widow so the book could have it's own cast and soap opera without needing to worry about what the solo books were doing, but talking about them as "characters who couldn't carry their own solo book" is as disingenuous as saying the same thing about individual FF or X-Men members, 60s Marvel never even tried with most of them. Hank Pym and Wasp are the only B-tier Avengers characters who used to have their own book that failed.

posts.sub: Still looking for this creepy ass short from early 2000s Animania HD
posts.com:
I have now discovered it was likely made by the canada film association but cannot find any mention of it.

As a child we had animania voom hd. They played lots of shorts or Animinis instead of commercials. There was this one that really stuck out because of how different and scary it was. It was very modern creepypasta esque. It was like a black mass of dots shaping into a scary, tall, shadow static looking person and going into three kids different rooms and going into their dreams. Anyone know what the hell this was called? I cant find it on any lists of their past programming. Yes Im sure its not a fever dream. Could only find 3 pics. No vids or name. It was possibly made by Monster Distributes. In 2004 or so. Its been bugging me for a few years. It was surreal and fairly intense. It scared me as a kid even though things like Monster House didn't. The creepy ass deep music didn't help.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>134555559
Steven Universe was covering a whole range of genres. It wasn't JUST a dramatic space war epic. The whole war was essentially the backdrop for the true core of the show: a goofball kid learning to hone his superhuman abilities and fix his alien family's centuries-long trauma. There was room open for comedy, romance, action, and musicals. SU wasn't trying to fit into one box visually, and it didn't need to. The comedic moments still hit, as did the emotional moments. It's fine if some people found the different styles distracting, but SU didn't have to look like Avatar: The Last Airbender to fit Ian & Rebecca's vision.

OK K.O.! definitely benefits from this approach a lot more since the whole show is one big joke that doesn't play ANYTHING straight. The stylistic variety only adds to its delivery.

>>134576412
>Amphibia spent the entire first season being nothing but episodic comedy
Not quite. It basically did the same thing as SU Season 1 by being more comedic overall, but still planting narrative seeds here & there and teasing at the grander story to come. Yes, Amphibia's first season feels way more lax and comedic compared to SU's, but the latter is still praised even today for the parts of it that were just a goofy kid tagging along on monster-of-the-week-style adventures, wreaking havoc on his seaside town with magical artifacts, and teaching his awkward superpowered moms about life on Earth.

Before SU dove deeper into the Gems' history, most people did still enjoy Townie episodes because the writers used to involve the Gems and their tech in mundane stories rather than the relatively more boring "breathing periods" that Townie episodes went on to become by Season 4 and beyond. And the disappointment some fans felt with the Thanksgiving special was just another case of them overhyping episode titles or synopses. Plenty still enjoyed seeing the Gems using their powers to prepare a human meal or to get Steven's uncle to be less prejudiced against aliens because by then they understood Rebecca Sugar's overall aim for "reverse escapism" that defined her show.

>it gained an infamous reputation due to its inconsistent art style
I'd say it's more controversial than infamous. There are two sides to this conversation: those who keep wanting to fit SU into a box and expected an angsty drama 24/7 akin to ATLA, and those who appreciated it as both a drama and a cartoony comedy. The prioritizing of board artists' expressive drawings over strict real-world proportions is what made the show visually interesting. THAT was the crew's specific look in mind.

>>134583319
That WebM is definitely one of the low points in the series visually; even I can't excuse it. But I wouldn't say it's representative of how the changing character proportions typically worked on the show. They were rarely ever that jarring throughout just one sequence. And SU was still plenty expressive in the latest seasons. The different styles gave many scenes some added impact, and you could tell when an episode was boarded by Jeff Liu or Miki Brewster or Etienne Guignard or even Sugar herself. Unlike ATLA, I'm pretty sure the Crewniverse pulled a lot of influence from '70s anime (notably Future Boy Conan) and really wanted to have this variety of styles and "imperfections" from their board team in order to take full advantage of the animation storytelling medium and emphasize that this was still very much a cartoon being worked on by a whole team of dedicated artists to service one showrunner's elaborate yet thematically focused story.

As for the running scenes, the intro was personally animated in-house by a lot of the series crew, whereas those shots in the movie were handled by the overseas studio, likely because they weren't given as much priority as Spinel's fight scenes. You could also argue the movie running shot works as a way of showing that all four main Crystal Gems were finally in sync mentally & emotionally since that whole number was about the main cast believing they were "finally done" with any and all threats or struggles for the foreseeable future. Compare that with how the Crystal Gems looked like a team of misfits that barely functioned on the same page at the start of the series and barely knew what they were doing raising this little boy.

While the changing proportions do lead to a few sloppy moments like that WebM, they usually added a ton the wide range of tones and aesthetics throughout the series.

posts.com:
>>134592910
It's been a problem for a long time.
Advancements in robotics exist, and now there exist robots who can literally do absolutely nothing but compute problems and solutions, and IM experiments with exact specifications to scientists (or other robots) who can then do the work.

So let's take this to one of the least important surgeries one can have done to themselves:
Gender reassignment.
We treat transitioning as a big deal IRL because it is a major mutilation to resolve a primarily psychological problem that should be treated with long term counselling and acceptance of reality.

But in a world where robots can be doing computations 24/7, and possibly experimenting 24/7, I find it hard to believe that transness is a big deal. Hell, it'd probably have been figured out to a point where it's commonplace and doesn't involve permanent mutilation. Hell, it's probably possible to regrow tissue and switch back.

Point is, I find it hard to believe that Claire is living in the kind of society where transness is treated with any real gravity: I have to imagine some people change their bodies and body mod just for the fuck of it, often with no real consequences since I'm sure it's easy enough to switch back.

It's like living in a world with Polymorph spells and treating transgenderism as it is in our world: ridiculous.

posts.com:
>What is this thread?
Every Wins'day at Win-O'-Clock we gather here and post links to the latest scans and rips of comic books.
Most links we uploaded ourselves, others we are sharing from elsewhere.
Some comics we've even purchased ourselves (but most we didn't).
If you'd like to help out, just ask and we would be delighted to tell you how.
Otherwise, be patient, be polite, and understand the simple concept behind these words: Not posted means not available yet.

>Where can I find old Win-O'-Threads?
http://desuarchive.org/co/search/subject/Official%20Win-O'-Thread/
http://boards.fireden.net/co/search/subject/Official%20Win-O'-Thread/
(Note: This finds the OP for old threads. If you want to search for comics in the archive, clear the subject field!)

>Where can I find downloads for other comics?
Warez forums/blogs, DDL-indexing search engines (like FilesLoop), torrent trackers (like 1337x) and other P2P networks (like DC++).
If a link has been posted on 4chan, you can search for it in the Desu archive (add "http*" to searches to return only posts with links).
If all else fails, just >buy it.

>Where can I buy comics?
http://www.amazon.com/
On the various publishers' webstores, and at your local comics shop.

>Where can I find an LCS?
http://www.comicshoplocator.com/

>Where can I find out when new comics are released?
http://www.comiclist.com/index.php
http://www.previewsworld.com

>How do I download from websites that only give me .exe files?
Untick the checkbox under the download button.

>How can I find this thread every week?
If you are using the inline extension go to http://4chan.org/co/official or use the option under "Filters & Post Hiding".
If you have 4chanX go to Settings > Filter > Subject and add the following line:
/Official Win-O'-Thread/;highlight

>And last but not least
Who's taking the blame?

I would say that she's more self-centered than selfish. She definitely does do things that require work and sacrifice on her part.

Shadow Weaver sees herself as a hero/martyr, surrounded by people that don't understand that she's right, that her theories, beliefs, and methods are invariably correct, and that everything would be better if they just listened to her. bruh, that's how a normal non-powerlevel wanked story is -supposed- to go.
>b-but if I just calculate this speed with that speed it's mega ftl+!
"no!"
That's a newtonian view of the world. It is not how EINSTENIAN physics works? VSBattles is stuck in the newtonian era and you can tell. You can't be sure that the numbers will add up the way you want to because of the train thought experiment.
I see it's an educational comic aswell, back in the day a lot of them took an EDUCATIONAL approach. The idea is the reader is to learn something out of it, which is why superman explains to the reader that time-space is related to the speed of light in the first bubble. What happens when one exceeds it is an open question which is why authors would often restrict to lightspeed or at most try to address the effects of it in some way; in the famous scene superman goes ftl and reverses time as a result. I assume it may have been a later comic or he didn't feel the need to use that power yet.

>>134591501
Cobra-La wasn't anything to do with Larry Hama or the GI Joe comic, it was a name the writers for the Sunbow GI Joe cartoon came up with as a placeholder name for the city of snake people in the GI Joe movie, with "placeholder" meaning they were just calling it that until they came up with a better name, but they had to call it something just so they could move on with plotting the movie. The part about Hasbro liking it so much they wanted to stick with it is true.

The lessons to learn from this and the Batgirl costume are to never use anything as a placeholder unless you're comfortable with it getting used for real, and never submit a design to your employer unless you're comfortable with them actually choosing it.

>>134585225
I never really liked the trenchcoat + cape look for the character. It always looked silly; like wearing gloves and mittens at the same time. It's like he's wearing an ulster coat with a comically long cape. An ulster coat with a reasonably short cape still looks off and makes him look old-fashioned even during the '30s. The pulps had him wear just a regular ass suit with the cape which I would say would look better, but in those days he didn't have the scarf so it was just the collar of his cape pulled up high.

For me, peak Shadow is a double-breasted suit with the cape, shoulder pistol holsters, and red scarf. Gloves optional as it'd make more sense for him to wear them yet gloveless harkens back to the original depictions which I think is neat. Alternatively, he could ditch the cape and wear a simple trenchcoat (open or closed as long as he's got the suit underneath) + scarf.

>>134570524
>she hasn't experienced any sort of physical exhaustion

If she did it would both indicate a low battery and conserve power so she could get to her charging dock.

If you want an IRL example, see the Nitro Hobbies 1060 Electronic Speed Control for RC cars. Its Low Voltage Cutoff Protection cuts power output in half when the battery gets low. Thus the car it powers gets slower at low power. An actual physical indication by a machine of a low battery.

It's still no more than 48 hours, here is a rough timeline:

>9 am: Emmy wakes up in Sterling custody, fully charged; Marcus runs tests on her throughout the day
>6 pm: she overhears the doctors' conversation, falls into the trash chute, gets locked in a fridge
>7 pm: the garbage truck takes her to the garbage barge
>8 pm: the barge takes her to the landfill
>9 am, next morning: the nabs find her, steal her arm
>noon: Darcy finds and wakes her, she blacks out again
>4 pm: Emmy awakes again to find that Darcy has fixed her arm, they leave the landfill
>5 pm: Darcy takes Emmy to Ginny's house (Emmy breaks a vase as the clock strikes 5)
>5:10: Emmy runs away
>5:35: Emmy sits in line at the DOA (we see the clock on a wall there)
>9 pm: Emmy's turn at the DOA lines finally comes up, although she is provided no assistance wahtsoever
>10 pm: Emmy roams the mean streets, lost and confused
>11 pm: the "musicians" nearly kidnap her, but Darcy arrives to rescue her
>midnight: Darcy returns Emmy to the mansion

Thus Emmy should still have several hours's worth of charge left. And for every time she wasted more energy by running or panicking there was a period where she was idle or unconscious, so everything should roughly cancel out.

Didio's Superboy ends with a cliff notes summary finale that explains what the entire year of the book was gonna have planned, Young Justice ends on a farewell for 1 character, but with too much open ends for many of the newer cast members who don't return for Johns' Teen Titans, Kon-El Superboy is reintroduced as a more humble character but without the character arc that Didio was subtly implying and Impulse becomes the person that his solo book was implying he would never become, another Flash and not his own hero.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>134586143
It honestly is fascinating how stories grow and evolve and change over time.
I told you who Saint Nicholas is, but I didn’t tell you there are two Saint Nicholas’s. The famous one is Saint Nicholas of Myra, he’s the one who slapped Arius at the council of Nicaea. He also famously donated money to a starving family by sneaking into their house at night and leaving money in the stockings they had been hanging by the fireplace to dry. Another saint named Nicholas was Saint Nicholas of Sion, who was a patron saint of travelers and voyagers. People conflated the two saints, and so the story of Saint Nicholas of Myra spread far and wide. It became a tradition worldwide throughout Christendom that Saint Nicholas would come to your house and leave gifts on his feast day, December 6th.
Martin Luther hated the concept of the veneration of saints entirely, believing they took attention away from Jesus Christ. He created his own tradition whole-cloth, intended to replace the celebration of Saint Nicholas Day. Instead of celebrating his feast day, celebrations were moved to Christmas time, and instead of the gift bringer being Saint Nick, the gift bringer on Christmas night was instead the infant Jesus Himself, known as Christ-Child or “Christkindl.” Martin Luther is also invented of the Christmas tree to replace the stockings. The tree was meant to be a reminder of the cross

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134586385
Father Christmas is a third and altogether separate character. When the puritans took power in England, they banned Christmas and all holidays, believing such marking of the days was a pagan practice. Father Christmas was a personification of Christmas season itself, and when the puritans lost power people would make pageants and tell stories in which Father Christmas would arrive and set things right. Pic related is an illustration of Father Christmas from the pamphlet “The Vindication Of Christmas” by John Taylor, arguing that the common man loved celebrating Christmas, and the puritans were only a minority. I don’t know if you can read it, but it shows a puritan saying “keep out, you come not here,” Father Christmas saying “sir, I bring good cheer,” and a working peasant saying “Old Christmas welcome, do not fear.” The Ghost of Christmas Peasant from A Christmas Carol is recognizably Father Christmas. It was also drawing on this tradition that CS Lewis depicted Father Christmas returning to Narnia and giving weapons to the Pevensies.
In the United States, these three (really four) figures, Saint Nicholas (who was really two separate people that had long been conflated together), the Christkindl (which is where we get our name Kris Kringle), and Father Christmas we’re merged into one. This is why Saint Nicholas who is also named Kris Kringle comes on the night before Christmas and leaves presents both in stockings and under a tree

I’ve had this vague idea for a storybook about the history of Santa Claus, designed to help kids learning Santa isn’t real.
Santa Claus is pretty fascinating, his history, because he’s an amalgamation of a ton of different historical, mythological, folklore characters, and his mythos is added to every year by different people around the world. My older siblings used to tell me they had seen Santa themselves, and when I found out he wasn’t real I told my younger siblings the same thing.
Basically I’d like to make a rundown on the way the story developed, spread, changed, etc. reassure kids that their parents weren’t lying to them, they were telling them a story and continuing a vast tradition, and encourage kids to make their own stories and songs about Santa to keep the legend alive

Eight Crazy Nights is almost a good movie, it's problems come down to;

1) it's too damn short for it's own good(like 76 minutes is too short for the story it's trying to tell) thus it has to rush like crazy in the back half, could have really used an extra 15 to 20 minutes

2) some of it's jokes are either too gross or too mean to be very fitting for a Christmas/Hanukkah film(the scene with the port-a-potty is probably the most infamous one in both regards)

3) Whitey and Eleanor are honestly too pathetic and weird, it just makes them being the butt of jokes for the entire town feel mean in a bad way

4) several of the main cast members(Jennifer and Benjamin mostly) get way too little screentime or development thus their connection to Davey feels a little hollow(this ties back to point 1)

5) the product placement is ludicrously blatant to an absolutely shameless degree(though I will admit the Spencer's Gifts gag always makes me giggle)

6) and lastly there's this really weird thing they do in several songs where multiple characters will be singing completely different things at the same time over each other and it's incredibly obnoxious and confusing, have no idea who thought that was a good idea


it's a shame too because it's gorgeously animated and definitely has a lot of heart put into it's production, and Davey makes for an excellent variation on the classical Scrooge/Grinch archetype that many Holiday movies/specials use, and when they aren't going overboard on unnecessarily gross gags or focusing too much on Whitey & Eleanor being pathetic weirdos the movie actually is pretty hilarious

posts.com:
When they were first talking about Spider-Man in the MCU, they kept talking about how they wanted to show us new stuff, and not the things from the previous Spider-Man movies.
Which is why they skipped the Uncle Ben death, great power speech, all the previous villains, etc.
Then for NWH to change its mind and give us that anyways, ruining the entire direction they were going in, while also taking the awful streaming trend of stretching the superhero origin across the entire first season, right down to the classic costume reveal at the end.
Did it make a a lot of money? Yes.
Did it have some fun fanservice? Yes.
Is HC, FFH, and NWH a bad trilogy together? Yes.
It's not that it's connected to the greater MCU story, and need to have seen the other Spider-Man appearances, it's that there's nothing else beyond the greater MCU connections.
It's that after the first and second movies set stuff up for the side characters, the third movie has no time for it.
You end up with this really good fanservice Spider-Man sendoff for the 3 recent live action Spider-Men, and not a good movie. It's a better Amazing Spider-Man 3 movie, than anything else.

>>134589845
Member berries are really just the garnish on what is otherwise a very well thought out Spidey Multiverse story. There’ve been tons over the years, and the ones that truly succeed all boil down to one simple theme “What does it mean to be Spider-Man” or in this case more specifically “What does it mean to be Peter Parker”. Even if they hadn’t been able to get Tobey and Andrew back, the story still could’ve worked with Tom Holland and three different versions of himself, but the casting of old actors enhanced it because audiences were already connected to them. I think the only legitimate criticism that could be made against it is that truly the crossover portions are the highlight and so one could argue there’s not as much rewatch value because everyone just wants to fast forward to the moment Doc Ock arrives and don’t really care about MJ or Ned.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>134589030
You clearly have never had a kid.

The world of child safe cartoons is an absolute wasteland. Nothing but mindless garbage and endless saccharin brain worm songs. And because there are kids shows, you will be hearing the same shit over and over again until Elmo's world starts playing in your dreams. The writing is brainless, the lessons simplistic and God forbid they have a joke that anyone would laugh at. It's fine this way, the target audience literally has never seen shows before and you have to start simple to built a foundation, but scanning kids shows to pick out the decent ones is a exercise in madness.

In comes Bluey, a show that is better in every single way to every kids show out right now. The animation is cute and expressive without resorting to cheap distortions. The characters have depth without being too complicated for children to understand. The stories are simple but in an fun an relatable way that reminds you of the simple joys of youth. And the lessons are complex! Things like how to handle a self centered friend, or how to handle defeat, or even how vanity can hold you back from true happiness are taught with the kind of elegance and entertainment that keep kids entertained and still send the message home. Bluey unironically made me a better dad. Even the music is the kind of instrumental stuff you can hear 10,000 times and not get annoyed by.

The show is a godsend to parents and I have some USB sticks with every episode on it to hand to new parents.

>>134592079
On the one hand certain shots can obviously only be done a single way with slight deviations.

Evidence in that the camera facing the person doing a forward thrust with a one handed sword will likely not look too different if we simply compare the actual motions, especially if this is supposedly done by someone trained in that weapon. If I asked someone who is trained in a martial format to perform a specific action and then ask another trained in a similar style, such as an uppercut. Then it is unlikely that their forms will be all that different nor will their motions change all that much.

However the second set on the bottom is clearly just ripping off the animation as there was no need to copy the motions one to one. This isn't so much an homage as it is just using them to cut out needing to decide for yourself how you want the fight to go.

Example of this would be Fight Gods, a youtube short that gained a bit of controversy as people discovered that the many motions were just him copying out of other animes and thus it made it less impressive and the animator apologized for plagerizing the other work.

A doodle is when a person doesn't put a lot of time or effort into a drawing, this is more a case of "I'm 10 and shouldn't be here, but I decided to draw your request". Well, keep practicing kid, make sure to visit /ic/ and /co/ can also recommend some starting material if you ask. Cartoon styles are deceptive: they appear simple enough for anyone to reproduce, but you need to know the basics of anatomy and perspective to draw anything that looks actually good. Good luck and thanks for your drawing!

>>134581100
A lot of people wanted Batman alone. No Robin. Doesn't matter if it was Dick or Jason.

Dick had been written out of Batman comics throughout the 70s. Eventually the Titans did become a smash hit, but that wasn't the reason why he was first exiled.

O'Neil is considered the one who saved Batman from the campy Adam West version. He brought Batman back to a more serious noir style, totally erased Robin. That run is the major inspiration for Batman: The Animated Series, which is why Dick Grayson barely appears at all.

O'Neil didn't like Robin. Jim Starlin didn't like Robin. McKean outright refused to let Robin appear in Serious House, even though Morrison wanted to write him into the story. Burton and his handlers nixed Robin from the wildly successful Batman 1989. Higher-ups had to force Dini and Timm to insert Robin into BTAS. The creatives did not want Robin, it was like pulling teeth.

But the marketing department wants the Robin brand for merchandising, because kids buy things. Kill off Robin and another OC Donut Steel takes his place, so people gave up trying to fight it. DC launched Legends Of The Dark Knight as the no-Robin book. The most popular Batman adaptations and graphic novels still generally have minimal or no sidekicks.

The fan poll to kill Robin was decided by less than 1% of the vote. The real reason is that creatives hate being forced to use Robin when they don't want to.

>>134585437
Maybe villainfag bait? It doesn't really matter because that section of the book has been lazy and poorly written, but anything with a villain feels more exciting. I disagree with the anonymous commentator who says that this title is now "The Amazing Spider-Villain." Peter still feels like the primary character, but he's hit with lethal doses of the "Vilains act. Heroes react" trope.

https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainsActHeroesReact
>"[Spider-Man] emulates the creatures he names himself after in some respects: he is purely reactive. A spider will often not bother to seek prey, preferring to weave a web and wait for the prey to come to it; then it acts. Spider-Man is the same. He cannot anticipate my actions — he cannot ever hope to. He can but react when I make my move."
— Doctor Otto Octavius, Untold Tales of Spider-Man, "Arms and the Man"

That said, when the villains are the main attraction, the movie changes from a tedious snooze-fest into a mindless popcorn flick. It's not good, but it's readable.

>On Earth-1610, ever since the successful creation of Captain America decades ago, the government always wanted to recreate the Super-Soldier Serum for military applications. Since the original serum was lost, the government has contracted private firms to help re-develop the serum, including OsCorp. Utilizing the blood of Nick Fury (the first actual successful super soldier and Rogers was the second) as a template, OsCorp created a prototype serum called Oz.[2]
Oz was created by OsCorp CEO Norman Osborn. OsCorp had since fallen on difficult financial times and the Oz Project was meant to save both his company and his seat on the board. Like any prototype drugs, Oz was injected into lab experiment animals to observe their reactions, including a series of spiders that mutated because of it.[20]

>Peter Parker had a tour of OsCorp and was accidentally bitten by one of the escaped lab spiders labelled OZ Experiment Arachnid No. 42. The spider's venom mixed with Oz and created a variant of Oz that successfully created Spider-Man; Oz worked. With OsCorp on the verge of collapse, Osborn tested Oz on himself, believing he had the necessary data he needed to recreate Spider-Man upon himself.[21] It created the Green Goblin instead, a flame-powered reptilian-like creature with a savage mind.[22]
You don't want to know the current status of the spider in 616.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134585321
After ditching the original triangular shield, Cap's original round shield had a blue round circle, a white circle, a red circle, and another white circle around a central blue circle with a star. But by the Silver Age even though Cap's costume remained mostly the same, the shield was cemented with the current iconic design that's remain unchanged since, and no WWII flashbacks ever acknowledge the other color scheme. Furthermore, originally the red and white vertical stripes on Cap's shirt stopped at a line under his armpits, but drawing from memory in 1963, Jack Kirby drew the stripes as going completely around his body and that became the new standard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Steve Ditko's theory of costume design was that the character should be recognizable in silhouette or with only part showing. So Dr Strange had the high-collar cape and the leopard-skin gloves (just showing his hand told the reader who it was). Spidey's underarm webbing wasn't meant to be functional; Ditko added it to make the character more recognizable in silhouette or in partial shots.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134577179
This is the first Zee that really made her a character. Yeah sure some anon and no one else will say she was good in 80's comics or something, but everyone else knows her from an episode and a half of JLU, being the rare 2 episode highlight of Justice League Action, then a rough start in Young Justice before becoming the bestgirl of some fucking terrible late stage cancer seasons.
>Then the "contentious" Justice League Dark portrayals that really do nothing new with her beyond a plunging neckline
In most of these portrayals she's just Batman's ringer, called when some magical bullshit needs to be solved. Something she does well but an entirely structural role. It never builds into depth. YJ eventually did better, but too little too late because most people stopped watching long before (at least until the child erotic memes dragged people back to watch the Zatanna-Zatarra-Dr.Fate-Klarion arc)

SHGs made her a tentpole of an ensemble cast and told real, endearing stories through her and the relationships around her. The postergirl for how damn well SHGs handled an episodic format with a forward chronology of time; characters that always had the same heart even as they grew, letting the series work out of order and sequentially. (If only CN had ever actually aired the fucking things, but if they'd let it succeed then they couldn't have justified their homegrown shovelware shows and gee billy 2 licensed DC IPs?)

That said, if they try to transpose her character traits into mainstream DC through some flashpoint retconned "new zatanna" for the core DCAU "inexplicably" it'll fail. In DC boilerplate hands they'll reduce her to some boss bitch and strip away all the femininity, deference to family, and playfulness that makes her work with her earned ego. Same applies the other way to why SHGs Babs is so markedly superior to the purple costume Nu-Babs of mainline DC despite being sampled heavy from contemporary Batgirl comics.

Ironic thing is that sentence is true regardless of the character.

With Ivy specifically the dryad direction they went is one of those rare times something "new" fixes something you didn't realize was broken and frees an existing character from past baggage. They never explicitly get into her backstory, but the hint at her dad being a (late) botanist has some strong Mr. Freeze vibes. If they ever make more media (game sequel, hopefully better comics) and it delves into the idea of her connection to the green being "unnatural", her creation wouldn't be "her" fault and that would make for some beautiful pain to turn into a further villainous fall. Something like rejection by swamp thing and "the green" making her go further down the (human) path of dominance over nature.

>>134592191
Well you remember how Dobby and Creature were just household slaves?
They're based on house spirits that do work around the home whilst you sleep and play tricks on you. They don't have to live in your house. They may follow you if you move. They may leave if you offend or hurt them, like any house spirit/elf/magical creature. You can give them food, sometimes in order to get them to do housework.
There is supposed to be something about giving them clothes but I can't find a reliable explanation/source.
They aren't all the same, it's just a common theme in English folklore. I wouldn't know if it's similar to the German Kobold (not a lizard, that's a modern invention, blame D&D or whatever).

Variant names are hobgoblin, brownie and dobby.

So yeah, not a slave race.

Anyone reading the new comic?

It's funny how volume 1 had about 45 issues and we never got a concrete reason for WHY Lunella wants to be a superhero, what her relationship with her parents is, or even what her parents do for a living.

Then volume 2 comes out and answers all 3 in a single page. Her parents have very dangerous jobs, Lunella has constant underlying anxiety that they'll die and she'll be alone, and being a superhero is her way of honoring them and living their teachings. It's a LITTLE clunky, but it's also pretty amazing how much this does to humanize a character who was always kind of a pill.

>Object teleportation/size manipulation
>Objects visible to her can be teleported and rescaled in adherence to how they'd appear to her perspective; if something appears far away she can "snip" it and move to somewhere else that she can see, like her hand. So as promised, I was doing some thinking about the Golden Girl setting, regarding Audrey's school life and Golden Girls Rouges' Gallery. Though to be frank, nowhere near enough. Work has kept me busy.
First, for the school, I felt we needed several things. Things like a name and of course characters to populate said school.
There's also the idea of if Audrey is well-liked or popular at all and what circle besides Iris and occasionally Billy she would hang out with.

So here's what I've come up with:
>Bartmen Secondary School: An upper-middle-class public school, known for its excitable students and its overqualified teachers. It's a newer school with newer equipment and state-of-the-art facilities generously donated by the PTA. Audrey's school.
>Zacheriah Creek (often shortened to Zach Creek) High School: The older and slightly more run-down school in town. Not a bad place to get an education, but stuffed with students with more overworked and no-nonsense staff. Has more...diversity than Bartmen, although this fact isn't explicitly commented on. This is the school where you'll find the other crusaders.
>Barnaby Girl's Academy: A catholic private school. Once co-ed, now just a school for girls. Has an excellent reputation with parents and authority figures, but not so much with the girls that have to go there. Roller Betty goes here. Or would if she actually cared to go and didn't always hang out at Bartmen to hunt for Billy.

I've separated Audrey from the rest of the Crusaders here because I like the idea of keeping Audrey relatively isolated from the rest of her sidekick companions when not on the job. I want there to be a vibe that Crusaders are all very good friends and are all stuck having wacky fun times in one school, but Audrey is alone across town having her own struggles in another.
Just things to make her dynamics with them a bit more interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134585927
Now, since most GG strips would be based around Bartmen, I figured it would be prudent to add more teachers besides Mrs. Bell and Mrs.Applebottom (I never like her, having a teacher with an oversized ass mess with the concept I think, but whatever).

If it wasn't clear before. The idea is that while it's still very much a public school, Sarah has been using her vast wealth to funnel money into the school and possibly helped with its creation.
I also like the idea that some of the teachers that are employed there are reformed villains the Sorority of Sisters have fought in the past.
Whether that joke is a background and one the Sorority isn't aware of due to Comic Code, or something Sarah is doing on purpose is up in the air since I can't recall what the Code says about villains giving up the life of villainy.
I know the Code states that villains must be depicted as villains, but what about villains that give up their life of crime and go back to being normal people? Not sure if there's a code against it or if that's a grey area that can be exploited, which can possibly lead to more interesting stuff in the future. But I'm getting ahead of myself.

Can't have reformed villains teaching kids in the GG era if we're still doing the code thing, it just doesn't allow for it. The code expressly forbids villains for ever having a sherd of empathy, which is very limiting for story craft. One of the many status quo shake ups done in Bullion was letting reformed criminals happen.
And ex-villain teachers is more of an 'I Know a Guy' thing anyway.
Sterling Steelworks funding schools makes sense, but I feel like Sarah would've donated money to EVERY school in the city, not just the one she had a hand in building/refurbishing. It's the truly heroic thing to do. Some schools are shabbier than others due to management, but no student is left wanting for up-to-date text books or supplies.

>>134586030
Anyway!
From teachers, we move on to students, which comes back to the issue I was talking about before.

Audrey's social life is a bit of a mystery.
Of course, we all understand the idea that she goes to school by day and fights crime at night...most of the time. But given that Audrey being a normal girl is half of the time we'll ever see her, I feel the need to expand upon some of the people she'll see in her day-to-day life.

So here's what I've come up with:
Audrey is a weird girl, but she's relatively well-liked by everyone.
Maybe there's a bully here or there that doesn't like her much, and maybe she's left out of the popular crowd for being too much of a goodie-goodie, but for the most part, she's generally well-liked and known as a good girl by teachers and students.

If people know her for anything, it's either that she's generally smart, she's oddly clumsy for one that's so light on her feet, she's a bit of a teacher's pet, or that she has huge ears.

I'd also like to establish that Audrey has pals outside of Iris, but due to Audrey always being busy with "work", she's grown sorta distant with them.
I can see with Audrey's developments, things have gotten even more awkward between her and her would-be friends, but due to Audrey always being a joy to be around in general when she isn't being a flake, they just brush it off instead of becoming frustrated.
I'd like to imagine that Iris is her best friend because Iris is the only girl that goes outta her way to do things according to Audrey's hectic schedule instead of trying to drag Audrey along to do this or the other thing.
I also like the idea that while Audrey feels bad for not being able to hang out to do other stuff, she deep down feels more guilty about not caring more about being left out.
The idea that she enjoys doing sidekick stuff way more than being a normal girl, and feels weird about that is something I'd like to explore.

Coming up with these girls in general.

>Felicity Fairmont, A popular and affluent young woman. Her father is a well-known and wealthy business man. She and Audrey are often at the same fundraising events and such. Way I see it we're following Robin rules, so that puts Audrey at like 8 years old at time of being adopted. We can push that back to 10, but remember that fictional 8 year olds are all Kevin McCallister tier monsters.

Then puberty hits her with the big boobs at, say, 14. I assume most GG strips happen when she's 14 - 18 years old. Let's not pussyfoot around with it, those are the ages of highschoolers typically.
Which means she went to elementary and/or middle school in Platinum City before going to high school, so loads of time for Sarah to fund the refurbishment of the city's schools.

If she's making regular friends, odds are she's making them while 10 years old before becoming a sidekick, but after living in the city permanently.
This wraps back around to her making friends, so they would also be in the 10 year old range when she met them.

Audrey and Annabelle are seated inside of a burger joint (Bun B's). They are in their civilian clothes. Their table is by a big window, they're sitting in booths across from each other. Annabelle is leaning in with her chin resting on the backs of her hands propped up on her elbows. Audrey is leaning back a little looking off panel somewhere. POV is if you were looking at the window passing by the booth.
Annabelle: "So the new Bun B's Beast is too much, even for you?"
Audrey: "Well..."

Panel 2
POV is from the window looking into the burger joint. Annabelle is sitting up straight looking down at the table in quiet shock, hands in her lap. Audrey is busy tying a napkin around her neck, licking her lips. On the table is a massive mega burger, its buns the size of dinner plates, at least four patties wedged inside with all the fixings. The burger is at least as large as Audrey's boobs. There's a small extra plate of fries next to it. Behind the burger is Roller Betting bending down, placing it on the table. Betty has the dead eyes of a person on the clock at a job they can barely stand.
Betty: "I hooked you up with some spice fries, hun."

>>134576636
The only real failing of Beast Machines was the designs of the Maximals. I understand what the designers were trying to do. They wanted a more ogranic alien look to contrast with the technological utilitarian look the Vehicons had. However the Maximals were taken too far and just looked off putting. Especially Silverbolt's bird mode and it's doe eyed look it always had.

I also wish they stuck with the original idea of Nightscream being a child survivor ala Newt from Aliens, would probably have worked better.

The rest of the show was great and heck the CGI holds up surprisingly well to this day. Animation errors notwithstanding. Certainly, light years ahead of what the Japanese would do with Super Link and Galaxy Force.

The story aspect aswell was pretty good. I liked the idea of Megatron being this supreme ruler and having legions of minions. That said the stars were undoubtedly the Vehicon Generals. Each one really elevated the show and I think each were easily better than a fair chunk of Beast Wars cast. The standout being Tankor. People didn't like the whole Rhinox being evil thing but at least it was an interesting direction to take the character with some in-universe justification/explanation. It's what I think the whole "Tarn=Roller" theory could have been. Also Jetstorm was pretty great aswell. I would take Jetstorm over Silverbolt any day of the week.

1. Needs more characters. The world is so fucking empty. Even if this is just a case of something like binomes from ReBoot. Hell, make it all DURING Megatron's enslavement during season 1.

I mean, there'd be more, but I've already expended enough thought on Beast Machines. My preference would be to either make a whole new cast, or tell a totally different story with the same cast.

>>134582084
>only failing
Besides plot holes; bad writing; repetetive plot going in circles; bad dialogue; characters ignoring what they said themselves an episode ago; multiple cases of deus ex machina (from plenty of super gadgets to "sorry afterlife, I am not ready to die yet"); characters changing their IN-SHOW (not even BW) personality for cheap drama; characters acting against how BW fans would expect them to act; characters acting like fucking retards just and/or pointlessly arguing to stop them from solving an obvious problem and keep the plot going (this is a big one and happens constantly); nothing happening for multiple episodes; repetetive fights with vehicons (you can switch them randomly and you wouldn't be able to tell which episode they are from); the setting of most episodes being boring, dark and uninspired; badly pretending, yes, PRETENDING to be dark, serious and mature (easiest, but not the only example: how many Maximals died? Compare to BW) and it all starts with not one, but MULTIPLE amnesia cases. Returning voice actors hating it is just a cherry on top.
Yes, the show had every chance to be a hit, but people making the decisions did not understand what made BW a hit. And they purposefully ignored almost all about it, thinking that 3D, a more serious (but not smarter - we want kids to get it even if they miss half the episodes!) plot and animal robots are the only factors. The fact that the series was written with respect for the source material and it's writing focused on what any particular character would and wouldn't do in a given situation went over their heads. Instead of asking "how would the story go when those characters are involved" they chose "this story needs to go that way, write the characters and events accordingly". BM was so bad that it killed US made shows till Bayformers came out.

posts.com: Remeber when SB came back and him and BA had a talk about trust and trauma? As badly as it was written, it ended with them apparently reconnected and willing to try to mend their relationship. It gave you hope. But hope is not mature or serious enough for BM. So the next episode SB is all about VENGEANCE and NO TIME FOR LOVE and even more VENGEANCE and the viewers say "the fuck had just happened". And the truth is: they wanted him to be like Batman. Everybody likes Batman, right? Batman sells. The name of the episode where he returns, The Darkest Knight? The White Knight Silverbolt changed into The Dark Knight Batmanbolt - get it? And Batman needs to be broody, he cannot connect with people, he must put his mission above all else. So they ignored that rooftop scene and changed SB from a confused, regretful guy into an asshole, just to make him more marketable. Yes, he had in fact THREE different personas in one show and that's not counting Jetstorm. And the funny thing is, once he becomes Batmanbolt he never does anything cool or important, mostly just broods in the background or argues, most often with BA, the only person with whom he had any meaningful coversation and to whom he has already opened his soul and episode or two ago - now, he pushes her away. Because Batman. They made him an asshole so they could do cool Batman shit with him, only to forget about it and not do anything cool with him till the end of the show. Fuck BM.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134585769
When I moved from London back home to Los Angeles, nearly the entire indie comic scene consisted failed or wannabe Hollywood screenwriters who didn't like comics and only entered in to comics because teachers in their screenwriting classes told them it's easier to pitch to studios and get optioned if they have a comic out. Companies like Avatar only exist to farm IPs out to get things optioned. There's very little money in selling actual comic books. The money is in the merch. The company that has your comic is banking on one of their IPs getting optioned and becoming a hit, and that will pay for the entire rest of their company. It didn't work for IDW, Boom or Avatar and it's not a good business model.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134585892
>nearly the entire indie comic scene consisted failed or wannabe Hollywood screenwriters who didn't like comics and only entered in to comics because teachers in their screenwriting classes told them it's easier to pitch to studios and get optioned if they have a comic out.
Based that's literally me. I don't give a fuck about "the medium of comics", I just want my story to be told. Comics is just the easiest and most independent way to get started. If I got a tv show or something that would be far better. Although I would still want to make sure I retain the IP rights and get on as executive producer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134586019
You're right. At the time I was snobby about it and looked down on them as "not real comic creators" but I was an ass. Now I understand they are storytellers just like me who were trying to achieve different goals than me. Even though none of the people I knew got their projects optioned, I have much respect for them for putting it out there and trying. Also them going in to comics with a proper longterm business plan and end goal was a lot smarter than me going in to comics because I like comics and wanted to make them for others.

>>134584559
Me personally I always kind of figured that outside of Cosmo and Wanda, Vicky was the most important person in Timmy's life and that would eventually turn his feelings of fear into something else. Not necessarily love or lust, but that when we look at the series as it progresses.

In the early parts of the show Timmy would include his friends, Chester and AJ in his wishes, such as them going into the video game as an example or when he made wishes to help his friends. When they were not around he would have his back up friends of Sanjay and Elmer to hang out with, excluding one off friends for an episode. However every time the presence of his friends also came with the complication of ending the wish after it has gone array as he could not reveal Cosmo and Wanda to them. So in one hand it seemed that as the series went on they were less and less involved in his wishes.

Now on a production side of things, the reduction of the cast is to save time, characters getting forgotten and even possibly to lighten the workload of having to do voices or pay a VA for that one voice.

If we look at it as Timmy maturing and keeping his wishes to himself since the extra people only cause more problems, it isn't a surprise to see that he isolates away from his classmates, Trixie is no longer a focus for him as why bother, there's no point to hanging out with your friends to go to the park when Cosmo and Wanda can take you to space for alien adventures, he can't bring Chester and AJ along on those times, so why involve them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134592600
But then we look into Timmy's parents, Mom and Dad, which for much of the shows running were absent at best and neglectful at worst which created Timmy's need for fairy godparents, which got him two new parental figures that he knows love him and are there for him. This for a young child would lead to Timmy caring less and less for his birth parents when Cosmo and Wanda do a better job raising him.

Ultimately, all of these other characters are disposable for Timmy, if they were gone from his life he would still have Cosmo and Wanda who serve as role models, emotional support and guidance for him because as he spends more time with them and other places like Fairy World, aliens and so on, a regular human parent couldn't impart the needed wisdom that a child like Timmy needs. His adventure when he got to his first year with his fairies where Crocker stole the wish muffin, Mom and Dad couldn't help him grow into the person who could do what was needed to save the world. In the Wishology when the Darkness was coming, it was only because of the experiences with Cosmo and Wanda that made Timmy into someone who could stop the Darkness.

His fairies are more important than his parents are. Because they are there for him. Which is why the last point of how important Vicky is to him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134592642
We have seen in numerous episodes that Vicky is a requirement for Timmy to keep his fairies. If she stops babysitting him, such as the many times he's wished her away, made her nicer, never had her as a babysitter, de-aged her to be her babysitter. He loses Cosmo and Wanda. Even if he doesn't consciously understand what he's doing, he subconsciously knows that Vicky needs to stay in his life. Which is why his wishes stopped being about trying to get rid of her and more on the level of making her tolerable enough to stand but not so much that he would lose his fairies.

Given that most kids don't even make it to a year with their fairies, Timmy has done what he can to keep them for as long as possible, using various methods. One of which is keep Vicky in his life. Eventually I would suspect that losing his fairies, he will still want Vicky around him, even if he doesn't really know why.

But we can see this as without fairies, Vicky would still be in his life. His parents leave all the time, never thinking of him. Sometimes to the point they don't even remember his name or that he exists. His friends can flake and others like Trixie don't even acknowledge him, but Vicky is a constant.

At the very least given enough time that his parents are gone, he would begin to look forward to Vicky babysitting him since at least she's there, she might not be nice to him, but objectively that's still better than knowing his parents will always leave him. Vicky would be a strange emotional safety net for Timmy.

One I could believe turning into some odd feelings for her. Against it might not be love or lust, but an admiration for not abandoning him. Given they aren't that far apart in age, after Channel Chasers, when it showed an older Timmy. I would not have been surprised if it wasn't Tootie but Vicky he married because of the connection they have. That he came back years later to try a relationship with her because he was drawn to her even after losing his fairies.

>>134595560

What is family guy but a reflection of dominant ideology at its finest? I find Family Guy particularly interesting because they utilize the character, of Peter, as a mechanism of control over their otherwise "free-thinking" audience. It has always fascinated me as well, how the Family Guy team makes Peter seem as an ordinary "every-man" when truly, he comes from an extremely privileged position.

If you were to take Family Guy at face value, as opposed to recognizing it is a satire of American society, you would probably think that its "humorous depictions" of violence, hate, and ignorance would be acceptable and appropriate. This makes it, in my opinion, extremely dangerous, not just in terms of humor, but what it says about "common-sense" in modern society.

Do you ever feel that Family Guy is "too much"? That it crosses the fine line of "good taste" and is just downright offensive, not "funny"? This is where I think Family Guy becomes extremely interesting as a psychological phenomenon, where this "offensive" humor, serves to give viewers a sort of "catharsis" or "release" from social mores, but can be argued by some, as simply being offensive for the sake of being offensive, and not having any underlying "social themes".

>>134594583

Not exactly: the early volumes fucked up by putting all of the Sunday strips in the back of the book, thinking they were all just recap strips/side stories told only in the Sunday strips. But early on in the first year or two of the strip, the Sunday strips WERE connected to the main story forcing the first volume to have extensive footnotes telling you to look to the back of the book for the next chapter of the story.

This fuck up made them have to vet the strips in full to find out what strips were recap pages, actually part of the story, or their own Sunday only storyline. As such, the recap strips didn't get reprinted and the Sunday strips that are not part of the main storyline isolated to the back of the book for future volumes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134594698
Confusing stuff. The fantasy stuff was always allowed and Great AM was invented PURELY to placate the strip's editors who got tired of dealing with hate mail from people complaining about the right wing views of the strip and how lefties were portrayed as Satanic evil in the comic strip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134594769

Looking back, I was conflating two different events because of the years involved and the length of time involved.

The Mr. Rune story was from about three months in 1984 from Leonard Starr while a previous writer David Lettick went down in flames in '74 after three months. It was more from his art than anything else though since he had a much more cartoony look for the strip with an odd look for Annie herself..

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134594865

I think that was an attempt to move Annie back towards her original appearance that was pretty cartoonish in its own right but that look was abandoned pretty early on by Gray. A few years in, she basically looked like she would in the '60s.

Anyway, Lettick did so badly that they actually stopped making new comics until about '80 and just ran reprints in the mean time which received better numbers than Lettick's aborted run.

I don’t know if you know this, but it’s incredibly difficult to make it look like a person is flying in film. You can’t use models, like you would for an airplane or space ship. It’s tough. The George Reeves Superman show had to invent a new special effect in order to do it, and the Christopher Reeve film spent an impressive amount of its budget doing the same thing.
I’m telling you this because the old Superman serial had a very… unusual solution to the issue. It was live action, but when Superman was about to fly they would replace him with a cartoon, and he’d fly as a cartoon and then become live-action again after landing

>>134586461
The typical comic book in the 40s was targeted at teens and young adults. Comics as a grade schooler medium was a product of the Silver Age/CCA and that was mostly an excuse by the industry to censor competitors and justify the shift to kid-friendly comics they were going to do anyway because of demographics (the baby boom caused a huge increase in the child population of America).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>134586437
>>134586521
Probably less. Big sitcoms are big budget but that's mostly spent on talent toward the end of their runs. Sets are of a higher quality today than they were 80 years ago, some things cost relatively more, others relatively less.

But on the whole I'd say a 1940s serial was likely produced script to screen cheaper and faster than a contemporary Brit "quota quickie" - they were making those in under a week for the most part, and vast numbers were created to stimulate UK film industry, so many in fact that even today the US probably still hasn't exported more movies to the UK than the UK has exported to the US (Netflix might arguably have changed things up, but Netflix and streamers generally have some weird definitions of movies vs shows).

Problem for lower-budget stuff like serials is that they were competing for time in the same screens, so that sort of flood of constant new material tended to affect how everyone worked.

>>134592429
I’m really bored so here’s a blog post.
The story of why The Shadow became invisible on radio is interesting.
Walter Gibson wrote the first episode which had scenes where The Shadow was able to sneak into a prison to talk with an inmate. The producer wanted to know how The Shadow pulled this off and Gibson said The Shadow rendered himself invisible by hypnotizing the guard.
In Gibson’s mind, and contrary to what is often assumed, the pulp Shadow DID have hypnotic abilities, albeit very limited — they worked in dark places, and were dependent on The Shadow moving slowly and quietly.
The radio people decided to run with the hypnosis angle to make their lives easier, since they never had to explain where and how The Shadow was hiding. But Gibson himself did come up with it.

posts.com:
I do kind of wonder about the dynamic of Anakin cheating on Padme with Ahsoka.

It works if you think Anakin is just a total hypocrite. We already know from the PT that he's a hypocrite; he espouses the Jedi when he dabbles with the Dark Side and breaks their vow of chastity. He talks of loving the Republic when he envisions himself as a dictator forcing people to bend to his wishes.

So, what if you push his hypocrisy a bit further? Padme is his guiding light, his shining star. Her purity and her saintliness are things he holds above all reproach. And in some of the old EU material, Anakin's real descent into true darkness begins when he starts to suspect that she's having an affair with Obi-Wan.

So: do you make Anakin a complete piece of shit, and have him fucking Ahsoka even as he's demanding purity from Padme? Do you have him cheating on her, and then being outraged at the mere thought that SHE could cheat on HIM?

It could generate some delightful melodrama if you wrote it well.

>>134582863
First cousins is on the border of where people are close enough for relatedness to matter (it roughly doubles the change of genetic disability over two random people), so different societies typically draw the line either just before or after that. However, sustaining first cousin marriages over multiple generations is a different story, and that does lead to meaningful inbreeding in the societies that normalize it. As with other cultural practices, people may strongly internalize it without understanding the underlying reasons why it's there.
